pros: Academic excellence: SFU is consistently ranked as one of Canada's top universities and has a strong reputation for academic excellence. It offers a wide range of programs across its faculties, including business, engineering, sciences, humanities, and social sciences. Innovative programs: SFU is known for its innovative programs, including its renowned Beedie School of Business, the Faculty of Applied Sciences, and its interdisciplinary programs, such as the Bachelor of Arts and Science degree. Research opportunities: SFU is a research-intensive university and offers numerous opportunities for students to get involved in research projects. It has world-class research facilities and partnerships with leading organizations and institutions around the world. Diversity and inclusivity: SFU has a diverse student population, with students from over 100 countries. The university is committed to promoting diversity and inclusivity and has several initiatives in place to support students from underrepresented communities. Engaged community: SFU has an engaged community of students, faculty, and staff who are passionate about making a positive impact in their communities. The university has several programs and initiatives that encourage students to get involved in community service and social justice work.
cons: Location: SFU is located on Burnaby Mountain, which can be isolated and less convenient for some students. Although the campus offers stunning views of Vancouver, it can be challenging to access for students who live far away or don't have access to a car. Workload: SFU has a reputation for being academically rigorous, and some students may find the workload overwhelming. The university's trimester system also means that students take more courses per term, which can add to the workload.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Burnaby, BC
pros: Interesting topics when teaching various subjects. Students at SFU are usually motivated and willing to learn which makes TA job exciting.
cons: Course supervisors can vary in their expectations and support for TAs. In some cases, they are really supportive and communicate with TAs all the time, while in other they have unrealistic expectations. The biggest concern is that SFU assigns certain amount of ours to TAs which is usually not enough to complete all marking needed and lab work and neither are concerned with whether TAs are able to finish their work in assigned time which puts TAs in very hard position especially since they are all graduate students with their own study workload.

job_title: Events & Marketing Coordinator in Surrey, BC
pros:
- Informal work environment 
- Casual dress code
- People are nice
cons:
- No room for growth - due to funding structure it's rare that new full time continuing roles come up here. It will be very hard to progress out of the role that you are hired in unless you move to another department.

- Lack of strategic direction - there is a lack of direction when it comes to the goals of the organization. Everything is a priority and it makes it very difficult to deliver meaningful contributions. 

- Lack of resources - wants to continually increase programming and work load but lacks resources to hire more people - this means employees are typically delivering the work that should be distributed across 2-3 employees. 

- Lack of employee growth mindset - even when career aspirations are communicated to the director level, they take a very short term view at employee growth. Wanted to apply to a role that I was already doing but was told I didn't have enough experience and would have to take $5k a year pay cut.

- If you are looking for someone to learn from the Marketing Management here is not experienced at all. Making it hard to learn any tangible industry knowledge as a manager was hired with 2 months of marketing experience.

- No option for remote work - makes you commute to the office in Surrey 5 days a week.

review_title: Love the people I work with
pros: Colleagues and administrators are very supportive when it comes to teaching environment.
cons: For the number of prep hours and time you put in, the pay is lousy, benefits are lousy, and very difficult to attain seniority to a continuing position. Turnover rate is extremely high, and you never can get full-time position. The fact that SFU was named top 10 universities to teach is actually misleading and a joke. Not all department employees get the same treatment. Noncredited instructors are not considered equal to credited instructors so we're at the bottom of the social/professional ladder and ignored. Nobody knows us because we don't count. Up until recently union fought hard to get research assistants decent pay (heck, SFU still owed most of them two years of salary), don't even talk about benefits.

review_title: Academia is due for major restructuring
pros: There is a lot of flexibility working in an academic institution since there are not a lot of centralized formal/rigid systems and processes in place. That allows for people to have a voice about what they think some of the solutions to problems are, or at least to voice their concerns. The staff benefits are incredible, much better than at other organizations I've worked with or explored employment with. The natural environment surrounding the Burnaby campus is stunning and there are a lot of amenities for staff. The HR department offers quite an extensive list of courses for professional development.
cons: The lack of clearly defined systems, processes, and structures in the organization makes for inefficiency and ineffectiveness in management areas mostly in terms of enforcing practices. There needs to be a better balance between creating space for opinions, and making difficult decisions and moving forward. Too often, I saw management sway to pressure, which is disappointing. In fact, there seems to be more consideration given to opening space than to ensuring the sharing of opinions is done respectfully, whether in person or through electronic communication. The politics of working in a large bureaucracy has never been more in your face than in other organizations I've worked with. There is bullying that happens and it is disappointing to see.

review_title: Great benefits, but definitely old school hierarchical and lots of dead wood.
pros: Great benefits and protected by union/association. Beautiful trails on Burnaby Mountain. The work I did was interesting and fun, and the pay was okay; about 10-20% less than private industry.
cons: If on Burnaby campus, be prepared for the campus to shutdown for snowstorms and be stuck on the hill at least 2x/yr. Parking is a nightmare during every student event or graduation. Limited food choices for lunch/dinner (you're stuck on a mountain). Re. supervisors and management: highly unionized = people stay in their jobs a long time and it would take a royal decree to get them out. Not a lot of movement higher up = old style approaches, very conservative, have to fight hard for change and will likely lose. Felt suffocated at times; ironic given that the students are full of new ideas.

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Surrey, BC
pros: It was an amazing experience to teach new students in an assistant role, while studying at the same time. I found that it made me grow personally as a student and that I was well supported by my supervising instructor as to what the expectations were for the role. I was also supplied a good amount of materials, although I understand that the quality of material might vary between instructors/faculties. I was paid, given feedback, offered union representation and invited to courses driven by senior teaching staff and fellow TAs. I was lucky to be well supported.
cons: One of the downsides to working at SFU might simply be the location as Surrey isn't a central region in the city (although it's accessible by train).

pros: Flex hours, dynamic environment. Always something new and interesting people to meet, network with people advancing in different disciplines and seeing where they go post-graduation. I've kept in touch with many students after graduation and it's gratifying to see them climb up the work ladder and become successful and appreciate where they recieved their education from.
cons:
Budget problems are always looming. Choosing between what is wanted and what is needed is never a good thing for the classroom. Can be frustrating when you need to skimp on the basics, even at this level of education.
SFU is a little isolated being up on the mountain. Not so accomodating to run errands during spare time since it takes an 40 mins just to go down and up again.

pros:
Do not work here ever
He ropes you in with a course that he will give you a good grade in then he suddenly has masters students that must do what he asks in order to graduate. You get no choice in what you research, he does not know statistics so you will be running made up statistics and then when other professors review your work you will look like an idiot.
cons: You have to have pointless hour long meetings each week that can be replaced with a tape recorder of the literally the exact same material. Then you have individual weekly meetings which accomplish nothing until right before the deadline of a project in which case you better be ready to stay up at night to get the work done. Example if a project is due a week before a deadline suddenly you have about 3 hours of sleep each night. The lack of respect for your private life is ridiculous.

review_title: SFU is a decent place to make a living.
pros:
You're in a learning environment - people are very inquisitive and hold their work to a high standard.
There can be a lot of variety, depending on the department you want to work in.
Work-life balance seems to be pretty important and people are definitely respectful of your time and need to have a personal life.
cons:
It's removed from the rest of the city and perpetually in a cloud which can become depressing in the winter.
Also, it seems that the management model is quite rigid - SFU talks about being innovative, but I didn't see a lot of interesting / riveting HR programs to promote adminstrative / staff employees between departments or functional roles.

pros:
As a co-op student within the school, they know you're there to learn just as much as you are to work. They're very understanding of your needs and what you need to get from this job to succeed in others. My department was extremely good in this regard. I even got to help in the hiring process for my replacement to get a feel for what it's like on the other side of the table.

You are treated like a regular employee at this job. No fetching coffee whatsoever.
cons: You're still in a school environment which may make it harder for you to get out of that frame of mind when working.

job_title: Assistant Dean, External Relations in Vancouver, BC
pros: SFU is a great place to work and has a pretty great culture of being innovative, progressive.  Also there is much less hierarchy than other universities.  As someone said, this is the only university they worked at that you can call the President, Andrew.
cons: Salaries levels are way behind other colleges and universities in BC.  There are discussions going on to solve this, but it's been years of complaining.  On the plus side, there is a good pension system, tuition wavers for immediate family and generous pat-leave.

review_title: Depends on where in the university you work.
pros: In a place of learning, with some generally good people.  If you are full time continuing staff, you can take credit courses for free.

If you are looking for a slower pace and mediocrity, you would be more likely to find  it in this type of environment.  However, it really does depend on the particular area in which you work.

review_title: A good starting point, then it's time to move on...
pros: Challenging environment. Large workforce with diverse opportunities. Acceptable accommodations/offices.
cons:
The benefits package was less that what one would expect from a government agency. Highly politically charged environment where everyone is trying to maintain their own little piece of the playground, this often interferes with making the "best decisions" and definitely works against fostering a sense of community (e.g., everyone is working together to achieve a common goal). 

The compensation is significantly less than what one could receive for doing the same job in the public sector.

pros: Great to work with Students and faculty
cons: Incompetent management and even though senior management knows they are incompetent they continue to keep them. The management bullies staff and expects staff to work overtime and says they can take time off but wont approve it-any reports to HR make no difference other than the managers becoming nastier -they have no training the management and talk to other staff about employees very unprofessional.

review_title: Overall benefits generally outweigh apparent pay differential
pros:
In general, work here is stable, interesting, and if you in the higher education mindset, almost every position is there to help students, research, and teaching succeed. 

Benefits here are typically very good.

Your experience may vary from department to department as there are very distinct working styles and even interpretation of HR/working/etc. policy. I love my department (IT), but there are a lot of places where the environment is less than positive, and others where it's a lot of fun just to be there. If you go for an interview, look for the personality match with that position and if it doesn't fit, don't turn away from SFU because of it, it can be just a departmental/group mismatch. There are a lot of different personalities and foci throughout the organization, and that can affect the work environment of every position.
cons: Some bureaucracy around the HR area may be frustrating for people who have worked in the corporate arena, and job progression paths are not always clear (ie. you can't go to your manager, in general, and say "I deserve a raise because productivity..."; even if they agree, they are bound by HR, union, and public sector legislation, contracts, and of course internal policy which can be changed, but holds a lot of momentum)

review_title: Good place to work if you do your job properly.
pros: Okay benefits. Unionized postions relatively safe if you have worked a long time. Some areas have good management. University attracts very competent staff and faculty for the most part.
cons: Pension plan a little dicey. Communication from management could be better at times. Like all government funded institutions, they are liable to budget cutbacks leading to job loss and minimal pay increases.

pros:
If you temp, you get to experience all sorts of different internal cultures so you can find your best fit.

Once you have a continuing job (at least for CUPE), it is very difficult to lose it.

Tuition waivers are fantastic, especially if you have university aged kids or you and your partner are interested in pursuing further education.
cons:
SFU is very confusing, with many different unions. The SFUFA for Faculty, APSA (an association) for management, CUPE for administrative staff, the Poly Party for trades and janitorial staff, the TSSU for teaching assistants and sessional instructors, and nothing for research assistants.

Pay for research assistants is limited to what you can negotiate with the grant holder - this means there are PhDs making minimum wage on campus. Canadian grants do not cover MSP or extended health, so you must pay 100% out of pocket.

Within CUPE there is limited growth. You do have opportunities (potentially) to take SFU classes to benefit from the tuition waiver, but that is negotiated with your supervisor and some are not accommodating. Once you hit the cap on your salary grade, you need to find a new job to maintain a raise schedule that is not just cost of living. CUPE also doesn't receive bonuses, and outside professional development is limited, as you must apply for reimbursement. Pay is low compared to similar jobs at other institutions. The benefit package is also not as good as other institutions (most employers will pay 100% medical and dental), although if you or your family is enrolled in classes, the tuition waiver is fantastic.
